document.affiliations: INRS-EMT, Univ. du Quebec, Montreal, QC
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: Many research efforts were recently spent to address the challenging problem of DOA and angular spread estimation. However, to the best of our knowledge, no previous work has thoroughly investigated their specific impact on the performance of DOA-based antenna-array beamforming. In this contribution, we address this issue in the particular context of wideband CDMA using pilot-assisted or blind antenna-array receivers. In the process, we also assess whether the generalized channel-matched beamforming (i.e., without DOA estimation or a priori knowledge of the spatial structure of the channel) offers a better alternative. Link-level simulation results in terms of required SNR at target BER of 1% suggest that wideband CDMA array-receivers, whether pilot-assisted or blind, are extremely sensitive to angular spread mismatches and that the benefits of exploiting the spatial structure of the channel (i.e., estimation of DOA, angular spread, etc..) translate, at best, in negligible SNR gains when accurate channel identification is already implemented. These results call for implementing channel-matched instead of conventional DOA-based beamforming.

document.title: An Error Probability Analysis of STBC MC-CDMA with Frequency-Correlated Subcarriers
document.authors: Lodhi, A.; Said, F.; Dohler, M.; Aghvami, A.H.
document.affiliations: Centre for Telecommun. Res., King''s Coll. London, London
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: The performance of a space-time block coded (STBC) multicarrier code division multiple-access (MC- CDMA) system operating in Nakagami-m fading channel with correlated subcarriers is investigated. Independency among MC-CDMA subcarriers is often assumed in literature which leads to idealistic performance bounds. The contribution of this paper is the derivation of closed-form expressions of the symbol error probabilities. We use the moment generating function (MGF) of the correlated Nakagami-m random variable (RV) to calculate the closed-form average symbol error rates (SERs) of binary and M-QAM signals with maximum ratio combining detection technique. Both, numerical and simulation results are presented, showing an excellent agreement.

document.title: Closed-Form Capacity Expression for Transmit Antenna Selection Systems with Correlated Fading Channels
document.authors: Wenwu Xie; Shouyin Liu; Guangming Huang
document.affiliations: Dept. of Electron. & Inf. Eng., Huazhong Normal Univ., Wuhan
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: In this paper, the exact closed-form capacity expression for a hybrid selection/MIMO (H-S/MIMO) system in the spatial correlated Rayleigh fading channels is investigated. There are two assumptions in this work. One is that the antenna selection at the transmitter is based on the criterion that maximizes the received signal power and only one transmit antenna is chosen for a transmission interval. The other is that the spatial correlation is present at both ends of wireless communications link. Based on the two assumptions, the characteristic function (CF) method is used to analyze the capacity of the H-S/MIMO systems. Then a closed-form capacity expression is achieved in this paper. A special system, having two transmit-antennas and two/three receive-antennas, is taken for example to validate our theoretic analysis. Results show that the analytical results are very close to the simulations.

document.title: Scheduling-Based Coordination Function (SCF) in WLANs for High Throughput
document.authors: Hojin Lee; Jaeyoung Choi; Taekyoung Kwon; Yanghee Choi
document.affiliations: Sch. of Comput. Sci. & Eng., Seoul Nat. Univ., Seoul
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: IEEE 802.11 WLAN has been widely accepted throughout the world. However, it has large overhead due to idle backoff slots and frequent collisions depending on the number of nodes. In this paper, we propose a novel medium access control scheme, scheduling-based coordination function (SCF). SCF polls the next station to be serviced by piggybacking. The selection of the next station is based on self-clocked fair queueing (SCFQ) scheduling in a distributed manner. Due to polling, SCF does not suffer from collisions and is efficient owing to the SCFQ scheme. SCF improves the system throughput up to 63.2% compared to IEEE 802.11 DCF. Comprehensive simulation is performed to compare SCF with DCF, PCF, and fast collision resolution (FCR).

document.title: Linear Minimum Mean Square Turbo Equalization with 16QAM Multiple Trellis Coded Modulation
document.authors: Nysaeter, A.; Otnes, R.
document.affiliations: Unik-Univ. Grad. Center, Kjeller
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: Linear minimum mean square error (LMMSE) turbo equalization with Gray mapped rate 3/4 1times16QAM and rate 6/8 2times16QAM trellis coded modulation (TCM) are compared on an unknown and time-varying frequency-selective channel. Frequency hopping is used for increased diversity, and the channel is tracked by linear interpolation between training sequence based estimates where a training sequence is inserted into the start and end of each frequency hop block. The TCM codes are optimized with regard to good low SNR performance. Turbo equalization with 2times16QAM TCM shows the best bit error performance, due to increased diversity relative to 1times16QAM TCM and better low SNR performance. The search procedure for finding optimum 2times16QAM codes is described.

document.title: Practical Multiuser Beamforming in WCDMA
document.authors: Haikola, V.; Lampinen, M.; Kuusela, M.
document.affiliations: Nokia, Oulu
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: In this paper, we present a multiuser beamforming technique that has been developed to overcome spreading code limitation problem in high speed downlink packet access (HSDPA), which is a packet enhancement to the third generation wideband code division multiple access (WCDMA) mobile communication system. The new technique is based on closed loop transmit diversity scheme included already in 3GPP WCDMA Release '99 specification, and the key idea is to transmit simultaneously to those users that have requested orthogonal beam weights. First, link simulations are performed to study inter-user interference effect, because the transmission occurs simultaneously to multiple users. Furthermore, system simulations are done with all HSDPA features in macro cell environment. The standardized closed loop scheme is the baseline reference and per antenna rate control (PARC) scheme provides comparison against open loop multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) scheme. The simulation results demonstrate significant cell throughput gain compared to reference simulations in one and three sector case.

document.title: Performance Benchmarking of TOA-Based UWB Indoor Geolocation Systems Using MSE Profiling
document.authors: Kanaan, M.; Akgul, F.O.; Alavi, B.; Pahlavan, K.
document.affiliations: Verizon Labs. Waltham, Waltham, MA
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: The presence of undetected direct path (UDP) conditions presents significant challenges for TOA-based indoor geolocation, since it introduces major errors into distance measurements. Therefore, it is critical to characterize the performance of indoor geolocation systems in the presence of UDP conditions. Until now, however, there has been no standard method of performance benchmarking for such cases. Towards that end, we present an analysis tool, known as the MSE profile, that can aid in this task. We use the MSE profile to analyze the performance of two TOA-based geolocation algorithms and show how the MSE profile can be used to gain insight into their performance, in the presence of distance measurement error (DME) models derived from Ultra-Wideband (UWB) measurements.

document.title: Decision Directed Iterative Equalization of OFDM Symbols Using Non-Uniform Interpolation
document.authors: Ureten, O.; Serinken, N.
document.affiliations: Sch. of Inf. Technol. & Eng., Univ. of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: In this work, a decision-directed iterative channel estimation scheme is proposed for pilot symbol assisted OFDM systems. The technique is based on non-uniform interpolation of irregularly spaced "pseudo-pilot" tones, which are generated by utilizing the soft outputs of a FEC decoder. The proposed approach is tested in simulated time and frequency-selective fading channels and results are presented. It is shown that the channel estimation technique based on the non-uniform interpolation of the extended pilots performs better than uniform interpolation at high SNR values.

document.title: Wiener LMS Based Multipath Channel Estimation in WCDMA and cdma2000
document.authors: Ahmed Ouameur, Messaoud; Massicotte, D.
document.affiliations: Dept. of Electr. & Comput. Eng., Univ. du Quebec a Trois-Rivieres, Trois-Rivieres, QC
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: This work is devoted to the problem of asynchronous multiuser delay acquisition and time varying channel tracking in DS-CDMA systems. A multiuser-LMS-like structure along with smoothing/prediction filters to improve tracking quality is suggested. A performance versus complexity analysis is conducted, in cdma2000 and WCDMA environments, over highly interesting settings including different data rates, channel types and mobile speeds. It has been concluded that the proposed multiuser LMS structure offers improvements compared with the correlator method.

document.title: On Rate Assignment Schemes for the Reverse Packet Data Channel in cdma2000 1xEV-DV
document.authors: Basyouni, A.; ElHakeem, A.; Agarwal, A.
document.affiliations: Dept. of Electr. & Comput. Eng., Concordia Univ., Montreal, QC
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: The capacity demands required to handle new wireless services such as e-mail, web surfing, and video streaming led to a new era of wireless technologies. cdma2000 1xEV-DV is considered to be the solution for the ever-growing demand of high-speed wireless packet data transmission. We investigate several aspects related to autonomous rate assignment schemes over the cdma2000 1xEV-DV reverse packet data channel. In particular, based on the developed rise over thermal model, we provide an upper bound for the reverse packet data channel throughput as a function of the number of mobile stations that are allowed to transmit instantaneously on each time slot. We also propose several autonomous rate assignment schemes that provide a significant throughput improvement relative to other published schemes.

document.title: Improving INS/GPS Navigation Accuracy through Compensation of Kalman Filter Errors
document.authors: Goodall, C.; Syed, Z.; El-Sheimy, N.
document.affiliations: Dept. of Geomatics Eng., Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, AB
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: The Kalman filter is often used to integrate satellite navigation systems with inertial navigation systems. Such integrated systems are especially useful for navigation of vehicles in urban environments where satellite signals are frequently blocked by tall buildings. The filter weights the measurements of both navigation systems to provide an overall optimal solution. Unfortunately, an optimal solution is only achieved when the filter has been supplied with ideal a priori information such as proper measurement noise characteristics and system dynamics. If such parameters are not perfect they can be detected and compensated for using an intelligent navigation scheme which is adaptable to different sensors. As dynamics are encountered, satellite signal blockages are simulated to test the optimality of the filter. A neural network is then trained to learn any residual deterministic errors which are then removed from future system drifts during signal blockages.

document.title: Complexity-Reduced Iterative MAP Receiver with Partial Sphere Decoding in Spatial Multiplexing System
document.authors: Hyung Ho Park; Tae Young Min; Kwon, D.S.; Chung Gu Kang
document.affiliations: Coll. of Inf. & Commun., Korea Univ., Seoul
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: In this paper, a partial sphere decoding approach is proposed to reduce the computational complexity of implementing the iterative MAP receiver for spatial multiplexing system, in which the complexity prohibitively increases with the number of transmit antennas and modulation order. The proposed approach considers only a subset of symbols with high a priori probabilities, i.e., more reliable ones, which allows for reducing the dimension of detection space. We design a novel reliability estimator which is used for dividing two subvectors according to reliability of individual symbol in the initial stage. Furthermore, a cost function-based partial MAP rule is applied to those subvectors so as to correct the initial estimation error in the course of iterative detection and decoding process. We have shown that the overall complexity of sphere decoding can be reduced by almost order of 2 in terms of floating point operations while maintaining the BER performance as close as 0.7dB to the conventional approach.

document.title: A Multi-Standard Viterbi Decoder for Mobile Applications Using a Reconfigurable Architecture
document.authors: Niktash, A.; Parizi, H.T.; Bagherzadeh, N.
document.affiliations: Univ. of California, Irvine, CA
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: Viterbi decoder is used for decoding of convolutional codes in wireless communication protocols. In this paper, implementation of a Viterbi decoder on a dynamically reconfigurable architecture is presented. Performance of this implementation for applications like W-CDMA, WLAN and WiMAX is studied.

document.title: Geographical Features of Satellite Visibility Viewed from Running Vehicles Based on GPS Signal Sensing
document.authors: Takahashi, M.
document.affiliations: Nat. Inst. of Inf. & Commun. Technol., Univ. of Tokyo, Tokyo
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: A novel scheme is proposed and demonstrated where satellite visibility viewed from running vehicle is economically and effectively evaluated with such low cost GPS receivers like automobiles are equipped with. Our preliminary experiment articulated even economical LI C/A 1.5 GHz GPS receivers can create enough precise database of ground feature blockage, compared to fisheye photograph method, if only two statistical parameters we propose are adequately set. This scheme demonstrates the geographical features of satellite visibility from a vehicle running in a metropolitan, a highway and an urban city. The latent possibility for this scheme effectively to create a useful blockage database suitable to the future-oriented vehicular satellite communication society is also discussed from the sociological viewpoint of the civil activities with the vehicles.

document.title: Exact Bit Error Probability of CDD MC-CDMA System with Frequency-Correlated Subcarriers
document.authors: Lodhi, A.; Said, F.; Dohler, M.; Aghvami, A.H.
document.affiliations: Centre for Telecommun. Res., King''s Coll. London, London
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: This paper presents the exact bit error rate (BER) analysis of a cyclic delay diversity (CDD) multicarrier code division multiple-access (MC-CDMA) system. By using the moment generating function (MGF) of the correlated Nakagami-m random variable and considering the realistic case of frequency-correlated MC-CDMA subcarriers (which is often ignored in literature), closed-form BER expressions are obtained with maximum ratio combining (MRC) detection technique for both uplink and downlink scenarios. Simulation results are also presented which show excellent agreement with the analytical framework.

document.title: Asymptotic Performance of Broadcast Services in IEEE 802.16e with CSTD
document.authors: Song, G.; Stewart, K.; Love, R.; Zhuang, Xiangyang; Yakun Sun
document.affiliations: Motorola Mobile Devices, Libertyville, IL
document.pubtitle: Vehicular Technology Conference, 2006. VTC-2006 Fall. 2006 IEEE 64th
document.abstract: The IEEE 802.16e system for multicast and broadcast service (MBS) is further investigated over [4]. It is shown that 802.16e networks can exploit advanced transmission and flexible resource allocation techniques to deliver high- performance MBS delivery within the constraints of the WiMAXRelease 1 system profile. A novel per-subcarrier SINR model for single frequency network (SFN) operation is proposed for the scenario in which cyclic shift transmit diversity (CSTD) - a form of delay diversity - is applied at the base station. The utility of CSTD for 802.16e MBS delivery in term of rate and coverage enhancement is investigated in detail based on the exponential effective-SINR mapping (EESM) for frame error rate (FER) prediction. In addition, an asymptotic effective SINR approach is developed for low- complexity approximation of the EESM FER mapping, and the proposed approximation is shown to be accurate for MBS simulation, while significantly reducing simulation effort.
